det.note: Assuming that the acacia in Haiti is this one, based on various online lists of planting projects. There are several similar species that are hard to tell apart as seedlings (e.g., Acacia mangium).

mtype.morph: Distinctive, curved leaf with several parallel midribs (the ‘leaf’ is actually a flattened rachis). A (large?) number of acacia species have a similar seedling form, so if there are two such species planted in the same area, care must be taken. Leaves alternate.

Twigs with pairs of straight, long, white thorns and pairs of shorter, curved dark thorns. Leaves approx. 2.5 cm long, pinnate, with 4 to 10 pairs of pinnae, each with up to 15 pairs of leaflets. Pods coiled.

det.note: Name via Sebastian, via Fairtree. Matches well.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Leaves on small seedlings pinnate, with later leaves bipinnate. Some intermediate leaves may even be present with opposite leaflets basal on the main rachis, and pinnate leaflets more proximally. Leaflets entire, indeed looking like fraxinus leaflets.

taxon.name: Anacardium occidentale L.
taxon.note: Native range probably does not include Haiti. Pre-domemestication species from NE Amazon Basin.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Petiole short. In older seedlings, secondary veins almost perpendicular to midrib. Leaf sometimes reddish.
Leaves alternate, elliptic, with glossy upper surface. Secondary veins not visible.
mtype.note: Location of original domestication uncertain.

taxon.name: Annona reticulata L.
taxon.note: This Annona species has fruits ripening flesh-pink, with tesselations on the fruit surface but not protrusions.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, held disticous in older plants. Leaf elliptic to oblong. Secondary veins impressed into leaf blade.

det.note: Seems that the Annona grown in Haiti and called cashima is A. squamosa, with the large, rounded protrusions on fruit.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, held disticous in older plants. Leaf elliptic, light green. Secondary veins appear pale on leaf blade.

taxon.name: Artocarpus altilis (Parkinson) Fosberg
taxon.note: Lam veritab is not generally grown from seed, only cuttings.

det.note: THTP captures 2021-11-01 to 2021-11-12 are ALTOALTA, verified by Karen Nicolas on 2021-11-12.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, tough, dark-green leaves. Youngest seedlings with serrated leaf margin, soon becoming deeply incised in older plants. This change to incised leaves happens later than in ARTOCAMA

det.note: All Artocarpus in THTP (ht) before Oct 1 2021 were labapen (ARTOCAMA), not lam veritab (ARTOALTA).

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, tough, dark-green leaves. Youngest seedlings with serrated leaf margin, soon becoming deeply incised in older plants. This change to incised leaves happens earlier than in ARTOALTA
Leaves alternate, tough, bright green to dark green, glabrous. Margin entire.
Leaves alternate, with wiry hairs on twigs and petioles. Margin entire.
Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets 10 to 30, serrate.

det.note:
Caesalpinia pulcherrima is very similar to Delonix regia, but has fewer leaflets per sub-rachis. A spreadsheet from Zaven gave one of the species planted in Freetown as Delonix regia, but iNat gives three dets of Caesalpinia pulcherrima and no Delonix regia. I (Cam, 2022-01-16) am going with Caesalpinia pulcherrima as the common taxon planted in Freetown. // Note also that some of the seedlings have tags saying 'African wattle' which is Peltophorum africanum. However, P. a. appears in all online photos with a mucronate apex to leaflets, but CAES0001 does not have this, and better matches images of C. pulcherrima.
2022-01-26: Confirmed, with appropriate uncertainty, by Marco Schmidt

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, bipinnate, with 7-10 leaflets per sub-rachis.

det.note: Calophyllum species are very hard to ID form leaves - thre are many species and all the leaves look similar except for general size and fine details of the veins. It seems from various documents that the Haiti taxon in plantations is C. calaba, which is not native to the New World (Diaz 2013). Asian C. calaba is a difficult and variable species (Stevens 1980).

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite, secondary veins very fine, dense and parallel.

det.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, held in a flat plane, simple; margin strongly wavy. Secondary veins deeply sunken.

taxon.name: Casuarina equisetifolia L.
taxon.note: This can become an invasive under certain circumstances, and should probably not be encouraged.

det.note: It appears from iNaturalist and other resources (e.g., https://phytokeys.pensoft.net/article/49602/ and doi:10.1007/s11676-018-0621-x) that Casuarina equisetifolia is the most common Casuarina in East Africa.

mtype.morph: Long, leaf-like twigs with reduced leaves. Superficially like a pine.

taxon.name: Catalpa longissima (Jacq.) Dum. Cours.
taxon.vern: chèn (ht), Haitian catalpa (en), Jamaican oak (en), Spanish oak (en), yokewood (en)

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite with long, thin peioles. Margin sometimes appearing sometimes coursely serrate but maybe just undulate. Leaves of young seedlings usually with pale yeallow variegation streaks on leaf.

taxon.name: Cedrela odorata L.
taxon.note: In most descriptions, C. odorata is described as paripinnate. This is the tree. The seedling begins with a distinct terminal leaflet.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate when young, becoming paripinnate (at ~50-100 cm tall), with 3-6 opposite leaflets. Secondary veins on leaflets faint, paler than lamina where visible, 5-8 pairs. Leaflets with less sunken veins that SWIEMACR or SWIEMAHO. ATTENTION: larger, paripinnate seedlings are hard to differentiate from SWIEMACR
mtype.note: commercially important

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Petiole winged, obovately. Leaf blade obovate, dark green. Secondary veins obsure. Citrus (hybrid) species are difficult to tell apart. Use this genus-level class for most citrus IDs.
May be impossible to differentiate from other citrus.
mtype.note: From the ORE website: "Wild sour oranges abound in most of the project areas." This variety may have long become widely naturalized.
A hybrid: Citrus micrantha × Citrus medica

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate; petioles thick, curved; leaves obovate, veriegated.
mtype.note: Common decorative plant throughout tropics. Appears to be planted in Freetown GS photos (5451a835-162b-481d-8583-aa10c0477ecc)

mtype.morph: Leaves emerge spirally from a hidden apex. Venation palmate.
Leaves opposite, broadly elliptical. With pointed interpetiolar stipule. Generic Rubiaceae appearence.
mtype.note: Comparing images on iNaturalist and elsewhere, I have been unable to reliably find features visible in photographs of sterile plants that separate C. arabica from C. canephora ("robusta"). The leaves of the former appear to have fewer veins than the latter, but... It seems better to lump both taxa into a generic class. It is likely that coffee plants will appear in Treetracker images from both uplands and lowlands.

2021-11-25. Pers. comm. from Aaron Davis @ Kew (via Alexandre Monro): Coffea arabica: leaf 6–22 × 3.5–8.5 cm, veins 6–14 pairs; Coffea canephora: leaf 12–35 × 5–12 cm, veins 10–16 pairs. ... So, having veins 6-8 might be a reliable character for C. arabica. More than that and it could be either.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, glossy dark green above. Rusty pubescence on twigs and petiole. Tertiary nerves depressed into upper surface of leaf.
mtype.note: Important in Haiti

mtype.morph: Leaves althernate.
mtype.note: Important in Haiti

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, long-petioled, golden-scaled below. Margin entire. Lamina deeply corrugated between secondary nerves. Leaf base cordate.

taxon.name: Cupressaceae spp.
taxon.note: Seedlings of all genera have narrowly linear, free, spreading leaves, of rather similar appearance. These are lost very early in the seedling stage of many genera (e. g., Calocedrus, Tetraclinis), but in others (e. g., Cupressus, Chamaecyparis, Callitris) the change from juvenile to adult foliage takes place later in adolescence as plants mature - the exact stage often varying widely between species. In Widdringtonia and Juniperus and some Chamaecyparis and Cupressus, juvenile leaves may occur on adult plants.
Juniperus and Cupressus are sister taxa.

mtype.morph: Youngest seedlings with opposite, needle leaves. Older seedlings and trees with scale leaves adpressed to twig.
mtype.note: 2022-02-06: I do not think Cupressus lusitanica and Juniperus procera (both Cupressaceae) can be told apart reliably as seedlings. Therefore this morphotype is needed where both may be planted (TZ). C. lusitanica is probably much more widely planted, though the ECHO project lists JUNIPROC. JUNIPROC may only be planted in montane areas.

taxon.name: Cupressus lusitanica Mill.
taxon.note: Widely planted in TZ and Ethiopia
Adult plants have tightly adpressed scale leaves on a twig, very hard to differetiate from Juniperus procera.

mtype.morph: Youngest seedlings with opposite, needle leaves. Older seedlings and trees with scale leaves adpressed to twig.

taxon.name: Dombeya torrida (J.F.Gmel.) Hepper & Friis
taxon.note: Syn: Dombeya goetzenii; wood density for D. goetzenii

det.note: There are many Dombeya in Africa, mainly in S Africa, and all have similar leaves. This det solely based on the occurence of this species in Kenya on iNat, and the species name coming from a local conservation org.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, large, round, hairy (visible in photos)
Smallest seedlings often with sessile, opposite leaves. Older seedlings with alternate, petiolate leaves.
mtype.note: This is a general, lumping morphotype for eucalypts, which are very diverse (even where planted as exotics) and show great morphological variation as seedlings age.
In East Africa, E. globulus and E. saligna appear to be commonly planted.

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite, broadly ovate, deeply serrate in seedlings, entier in adults.
Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets elliptical, entire. Secondary veins obscure.
mtype.note: Important in Haiti

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, pinnately lobed. Lobes opposite, 4 pairs with terminal, narrow, with parallel sides, not tending towards pinnate sub-lobing.
mtype.note: https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/35613549, https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/34438302

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, pinnately to bipinnately lobed. lobes with serrate margins, tending towards pinnate sub-lobing. Primary lobes up to 10 pairs, opposite on 'rachis'.
Leaves opposite, palmately compound.
mtype.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Leaflets two, asymmetric.
mtype.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.

mtype.morph: Leaves ovoid, long-petioled, pale below but not golden. Seven basal veins originating from leaf base. Leaf base deeply cordate with margins overlapping. Leaf margin serrate.

det.note: Might also be M. emarginata, but that tends indeed to have a more rounded, emarginate leaf apex.

mtype.morph: Small, opposite, coriaceous leaves with pale midrib. Longer twigs tend towards growing horizontally; then leaves are held in a single plane.
Leaves palmate. Not clear yet if alternate or opposite.

mtype.note: A Meliaceae. Possibly the seedling of SWIEMAHO. Similar also to the known SWIEMACR seedling, but has more, and more-regular, secondary veins.
mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, elliptical or obovate, base acute. Upper leaf surface shiny. Petiole long, with a knee at junction with leaf blade.
Leaves alternate. In young seedlings, leaf consists of winged rachis and only two opposite leaflets.
mtype.note: So far (2021-03-23) just making assumption that the Inga in Haiti planting photos is this one.

taxon.name: Juniperus procera Hochst. ex Endl.
taxon.vern: African pencil cedar (en), African juniper (en), mtarakwa (tz)
taxon.range: Montane forests of East Africa and Arabia
taxon.note: Adult plants have tightly adpressed scale leaves on a twig, very hard to differetiate from Cupressus lusitanica.

mtype.morph: Youngest seedlings with opposite, needle leaves. Older seedlings and trees with scale leaves adpressed to twig.
Leaves alternate, glossy above. Secondary veins deeply sunken above. Tertiary veins densely parallel and visible in photos. Margin with distinctive 'pinching' or notching at end of secondary veins.
Leaves alternate. Petiole long. Leaves long, leathery, with secondary veins almost perpendicular to the midrib. Compare with cashew.
mtype.note: Can be pruned multiple times for firewood

taxon.name: Manilkara zapota (L.) P.Royen
taxon.range: Southern Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, elliptic, glossy above. Secondary veins inconspicuous. Compare with ANNOMURI.

det.note: Thanks to Nobby Cordeiro and Henry Ndangalasi for the determination of Fairtree seedlings, 2021-11-16.
The seedlings in Kenya seem to have leaflets that are less rounded at the base and more acute. But iNat has only M. lutea in Kenya, so I've added the KE photos to MARKLUTE.

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite, simple in youngest seedlings, imparipinnate after ~tenth leaf (with three leaflets, then five, then seven). Stipules large, appearing interpetiolar. Margin serrate (in seedlings).
Rachis of leaves (in young plants?) can be winged and may be confused with Inga.
Leaves alternate, bipinnate. Leaflets oval.
mtype.note: Planted by Forest Nation in Haiti

mtype.morph: Very large, monocot leaves. Classic banana form.
Leaves alternate. Tending towards obovate, sometime reddish when young. Very generic tropical tree seedling leaves.
mtype.note: Karen: "Seedlings requires a lot of water the first 3 years". Likely exotic in Haiti: first humans to Haiti ~1,200 AD, well after avocado was domesticated.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, simple. Leaf apex deeply cleft.

mtype.note: In Tanzania, the main restoration Pinus species appears to be Pinus patula Schltdl. & Cham., a native of Mexico. Most of the images are placed here by inferrence “Pinus in TZ”

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, bijugate (paripinnate with one pair of leflets). Twig with thorns.

taxon.name: Prosopis juliflora (Sw.) DC.
taxon.range: Mexico, South America and the Caribbean

mtype.note: Important in Haiti

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Stem and petiole often reddish. Margin finely serrate (but not visible in most photos).

taxon.name: Psidium guajava L.
taxon.range: Caribbean, Central America and South America

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite. Secondary veins deeply sunken into leaf (from above).
Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite, 6-16, elliptic. Secondary veins obscure. Leaflets similar to GLIRSEPI, but leaf without a terminal leaflet.
mtype.note: Previously called Cassia siamea.
Important in Haiti.

taxon.name: Simarouba glauca DC. var. latifolia Cronq.
taxon.vern: bwa fwenn (ht), bwa blan (ht), doliv (ht), simarouba (en), princess tree (ht)

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, imparipinnate. Leaflets alternate, 6-7 pairs.
Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite, 3-5 pairs, leaflets opposite. Secondary veins pale, at right angles to leaflet primary vein.
mtype.note: This may just be a juvenile SIMAGLAU, but the opposite leaflets and prominant secondary veins suggest a different species.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Young plants have simple leaves, with long petiole and swollen 'knee', older plants transition through a brief imparipinnate phase, soon becoming paripinnate. Secondary veins deeply sunken above (cf. CEDRODOR), and curving more rapidly in their distal third than CEDRODOR.
mtype.note: Identity of common saplings in MACAO confirmed by Maria C. on 2021-11-16.
See simple leaved seedlings in iNat obs 105493254 and 98757847.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate, older seedlings and tree paripinnate. Secondary veins sunken, leaflets appearing leathery and dark green, more ovate than SWIEMACR. Smallest seedlings no known yet, but probably simple (see SWIEMACR).

det.note: Det from species list from Cranes Conservation

mtype.morph: Leaves opposite, dark green above, narrow-ish and appearing leathery.
Leaves alternate, paripinnate. Leaflets opposite on rachis, in 7-8 pairs, oblong in shape.
Leaves opposite, large, obovate, almost sessile.
Leaves alternate, obovate. Young seedlings still show the first pair of kidney-shaped leaves.

mtype.note: There are many Terminalia native to West Africa, plus the ubiquitous T. catappa, and most Terminalia are similar as seedlings. Inferrence (weak): {local name from Freetown planters = ronko} + {ronko in online wood database = T. ivorensis} + {images = terminalia} => {images in Freetown = T. ivorensis}.

mtype.morph: Leaves alternate. Petiole narrow, at an angle to plane of leaf, and swollen ‘knee’ at petiole apex. Leaves large, dark-green, with strongly curving secondary veins. Older plants show a ‘V’ pair of basal secondary veins, but these are less obvious in the smaller plants.

country.note:
1. from https://www.theevertree.com/haiti "Agroforestry Species" Gliricidia sepium Leucaena leucocephala Lysiloma sabicu Benth. Roystonea borinquena Senna siamea Swietenia mahagoni
2. from Landscape Factors and Restoration Practices Associated with Initial Reforestation Success in Haiti Starry D. Sprenkle-Hyppolite et al. Azadirachta indica, neem, "nim" Enterolobium cyclocarpum, “bwa taniswouj” Eucalyptus camaldulensis, “ekiliptus”

RUBIA Nerium oleander (Oleander) Ornamental Palms Peltophorum africanum (African wattle) Persea americana (Avocado) Polyalthia pendula (Willow tree) Psidium guajava (Guava) Senna semia (Siamese Cassia) * Tamarindus indica (Tamarind) * Tectonia grandis (Teak) * Terbanamontana coronaria (Pinwheel flower) Terbanamontana corymbosa (Flower of love) Thevetia peruvania (Yellow Oleander) Thunbergia erecta Xylopia aethiopica (Spice tree)

## Usambaras
Usambara species from https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0250859 (via KNB): Albizia gummifera, Albizia sp, Allanblackia stuhlmannii, Allophyllus melliodorus, Anisophyllea obtusifolia, Annickia kummeriae, Anthocleista grandiflora, Antiaris toxicaria, Bersama abyssinica, Blighia unijugata, Bridelia micrantha, Cedrela odorata, Celtis gomphophylla, Cephalosphaera usambarensis, Chrysophyllum perpulchrum, Cinnamomum camphora, Cussonia zimmermannii, Drypetes gerrardii, Ficus altissima, Ficus natalensis, Ficus sp., Ficus sp. [strangler], Ficus sp. [triangular leaves], Greenwayodendron suaveolens, Grevillea robusta, Harungana madagascariensis, Macaranga capensis, Maesa lanceolata, Maesopsis eminii, Maranthes goetzeniana, Newtonia buchananii, Odyendea zimmermannii, Parinari excelsa, Polyscias fulva, Psidium guajava, Rauvolfia caffra, Rhodognaphalon schumannianum, Rinorea ilicifolia, Rubiaceae sp, Rubiaceae sp2, Sapium ellipticum, Sorindeia madagascariensis, Strombosia scheffleri, Synsepalum cerasiferum, Syzygium guineense, Tricalysia sp., Trichilia dregeana, Trichilia emetica, Trilepisium madagascariense, unknown, unknown spp 1, Xylopia aethiopica, Xymalos monospora, Zanha golungensis, Zanthoxylum usambarense

(From Ezra) ECHO East Africa Impact Center plants: Afzelai quansensis (pod mahogony, mbabakofi), Juniperus procera (pencil cedar, mtarakwa), Khaya nyasica (red mahogony, mkangazi), Milletia stuhlmannii (milletia, mkuunge), Ocotea usambarensis (E African camphor, mkulo), Olea capensis (East african olive, loliondo), Osyris lanceolate (sandalwood, msandalii), Podocarpus falcatus (yellow wood, mpodo), Prunus africana (African teak, mkonde), Bracylaena huilensis (silver oak, muhuhu), Dalbergia melanoxylon (blackwood, mpingo).
